title: ‘A Safe Sidewalk, Not a Heart Attack’
content:
Howard Smith dug his shovel upright into the snow and stared admiringly at the strip of sidewalk before him. The path in front of his Upper East Side building was fully cleared and wide enough for a double stroller.

“Now that’s a beautiful sidewalk,” he said.

Mr. Smith is 91 years old, and still handles snow-clearing duties himself. After decades of digging, he has developed a few cardinal rules.

“What you want to do is mark your line from the top and then scoop it from below,” he explained, tossing a clump of ice to the side. “And salt is absolutely crucial.”

A few passers-by offered to lend Mr. Smith a hand, but he politely demurred.

“The key for me is to use a small shovel,” he said. “I want a safe sidewalk, not a heart attack.”

https://twitter.com/NoahRemnick/status/691308898066759680

parent.title: Winter Storm on East Coast: Live Updates

content_expanded:
Howard Smith dug his shovel upright into the snow and stared admiringly at the strip of sidewalk before him. The path in front of his Upper East Side building was fully cleared and wide enough for a double stroller.

“Now that’s a beautiful sidewalk,” he said.

Mr. Smith is 91 years old, and still handles snow-clearing duties himself. After decades of digging, he has developed a few cardinal rules.

“What you want to do is mark your line from the top and then scoop it from below,” he explained, tossing a clump of ice to the side. “And salt is absolutely crucial.”

A few passers-by offered to lend Mr. Smith a hand, but he politely demurred.

“The key for me is to use a small shovel,” he said. “I want a safe sidewalk, not a heart attack.”

91-year-old Howard Smith shoveling his sidewalk after the storm pic.twitter.com/UtgX1pcWLN

— Noah Remnick (@NoahRemnick) January 24, 2016

title: Enforcing Snow Shoveling Rules
content:
[nytmedia id="100000004164696" crop="592" type="image"]

At a news conference with Mayor Bill de Blasio, the sanitation commissioner, Kathryn Garcia, said that residents are supposed to have shoveled outside their homes or businesses four hours after the last snowflake falls. 

But, responding to a question about the many New Yorkers who have been ticketed in past snowstorms, she said enforcement agents would be focused instead on people who were shoveling snow out of large private parking lots into the street.

parent.title: Winter Storm on East Coast: Live Updates

title: Mayor Promises to Dig Out Queens
content:
Even as Mayor Bill de Blasio credited a travel ban with helping sanitation workers plow the roads, he also acknowledged at a news conference that roads in a number of neighborhoods in Queens were still buried.

City officials attributed the lag there to the borough’s size, narrow back roads and elevated snowfall totals. The mayor noted that 850 plows were at work in Queens late Sunday morning, including some that had been transferred from other boroughs.

“That’s going to be a high point of focus today,” he said.

Alternate side parking is suspended across the city through Friday.

title: ‘A Series of Bad Decisions’
content:
Of the dozens of motorists ticketed for violating a driving ban in New York City during the blizzard, a Brooklyn man was the worst offender, a police official said during a news conference on Sunday.

The man "made a series of bad decisions" that led to his arrest, James P. O'Neill, the chief of department for the New York Police Department, said.

In addition to driving after the ban was put into place, the man was speeding and drove through two red lights, Chief O'Neill said. 

The Police Department identified the driver as Aleksey Tsvetkov, 36, of Bergen Beach, Brooklyn. He was driving a white Lexus before he was arrested around 2:20 a.m. on Sunday near the intersection of 86th Street and Avenue U in Gravesend, the police said.

When he was pulled over, Mr. Tsvetkov smelled of alcohol and had a "flush complexion" and "watery eyes," a department spokesman said.

"So we locked him up for DWI," Chief O'Neill said.

Mr. Tsvetkov was booked on six charges, including criminal possession of a controlled substance, reckless driving, unlawful possession of marijuana, refusal to take a breath test and driving while intoxicated.

He was also charged with violation of local law, which was the mayor's travel ban.

parent.title: Winter Storm on East Coast: Live Updates

title: Where Snowfall Records Fell
content:
[nytmedia id="100000004164615" crop="592" type="image"]

Where did the snowfall break a record, or come close? 

Patrick Burke, a meteorologist at the National Weather Service’s national forecasting center in College Park, Md., came up with this list, but with a caveat.

“It’s still early enough that these should be considered preliminary," he said. "With it being a historic event there will be a review of the numbers.''

Baltimore-Washington International Airport had a record snowfall of 29.2 inches. The previous record was 26.8 inches, set Feb 16-18, 2003.

At Reagan National Airport in Washington, meteorologists recorded
17.8 inches, tied for fourth place with a February 2010 storm, behind 
28 inches in January 1922; 20 inches in February 1899; and 18.7 inches in February 1979.

Philadelphia had 22.4 inches, making it the city's fourth-snowiest storm.

Allentown, Pa., had 31.9 inches and Harrisburg, Pa., had 30.2 inches. Both were reported as records, although historic data was not immediately available. 

In Central Park, 26.8 inches fell, just one-tenth of an inch behind the No. 1 storm, in February 2006.

parent.title: Winter Storm on East Coast: Live Updates

content_expanded:
Where did the snowfall break a record, or come close?

Patrick Burke, a meteorologist at the National Weather Service’s national forecasting center in College Park, Md., came up with this list, but with a caveat.

“It’s still early enough that these should be considered preliminary,” he said. “With it being a historic event there will be a review of the numbers.”

Baltimore-Washington International Airport had a record snowfall of 29.2 inches. The previous record was 26.8 inches, set Feb 16-18, 2003.

At Reagan National Airport in Washington, meteorologists recorded
17.8 inches, tied for fourth place with a February 2010 storm, behind
28 inches in January 1922; 20 inches in February 1899; and 18.7 inches in February 1979.

Philadelphia had 22.4 inches, making it the city’s fourth-snowiest storm.

Allentown, Pa., had 31.9 inches and Harrisburg, Pa., had 30.2 inches. Both were reported as records, although historic data was not immediately available.

In Central Park, 26.8 inches fell, just one-tenth of an inch behind the No. 1 storm, in February 2006.

title: Christie Praises Response Without ‘Heavy Hand of Government’
content:
[nytmedia id="100000004164612" crop="592" type="image"]

Without naming names, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey contrasted his approach to the blizzard with those of governors who ordered their residents off the roads on Saturday.

Speaking with a tone of validation at a news conference in Bedminster, N.J., Mr. Christie thanked the people of his state for staying off the highways and out of the way of snowplows without his “having to use the heavy hand of government to put mandatory travel bans in place.”

Other states, including New York, did issue travel bans.

Mr. Christie said the only vehicles he had seen while traveling around the state were emergency vehicles and plows. He praised a “good last 24 hours in terms of emergency response” to the storm, which brought 24 to 30 inches of snow on the northern part of the state.

“You’re free to go out and do what you want to do,” he said.

At a later news conference about New York State's response to the storm, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo defended the travel ban and thanked residents for their cooperation.

"I know they were inconvenienced yesterday when I put the travel ban in place," he said. "New Yorkers are not accustomed to being constricted. What the ban did for us was it protected the public and it allowed the crews to actually clean the roads. When you look back, it was the right decision because we have had success in both areas."

parent.title: Winter Storm on East Coast: Live Updates

Speaking with a tone of validation at a news conference in Bedminster, N.J., Mr. Christie thanked the people of his state for staying off the highways and out of the way of snowplows without his “having to use the heavy hand of government to put mandatory travel bans in place.”

Other states, including New York, did issue travel bans.

Mr. Christie said the only vehicles he had seen while traveling around the state were emergency vehicles and plows. He praised a “good last 24 hours in terms of emergency response” to the storm, which brought 24 to 30 inches of snow on the northern part of the state.

“You’re free to go out and do what you want to do,” he said.

At a later news conference about New York State’s response to the storm, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo defended the travel ban and thanked residents for their cooperation.

“I know they were inconvenienced yesterday when I put the travel ban in place,” he said. “New Yorkers are not accustomed to being constricted. What the ban did for us was it protected the public and it allowed the crews to actually clean the roads. When you look back, it was the right decision because we have had success in both areas.”

title: Sorry Kids, School Will Be in Session
content: Schools will be open on Monday, Mayor Bill de Blasio said at a news conference in Downtown Brooklyn. Asked by a reporter what would close schools if not 26.8" of snow, the mayor said "timing could not have been better" and the Sanitation Department had done such a good job that students could safely return to school on Monday. Check @NYCSchools on Twitter for details.

parent.title: Winter Storm on East Coast: Live Updates

content_expanded:
Schools will be open on Monday, Mayor Bill de Blasio said at a news conference in Downtown Brooklyn.

Asked by a reporter what would close schools if not 26.8″ of snow, the mayor said “timing could not have been better” and the Sanitation Department had done such a good job that students could safely return to school on Monday.

Check @NYCSchools on Twitter for details.

title: A Plane Lands. At Kennedy, That’s News.
content:
[nytmedia id="100000004164622" crop="592" type="image"]

After a day of canceled flights, an Air India flight touched down at the sole open runway at Kennedy International Airport at 7:10 a.m., Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said.

And then, there were three more hours of silence in the skies, until a JetBlue flight took off for the Bahamas at 10 a.m.

In total, 12 planes arrived at Kennedy, and four departed between 7 and 11:45 a.m., according to the Federal Aviation Administration.

Nationally, more than 3,700 flights were canceled on Sunday and there have been more than 2,400 delays, according to FlightAware, a website that tracks flights. 

Kennedy Airport was barren on Sunday morning, with only two taxis in front of one terminal and a scattering of would-be passengers. Many were sleeping, others walking around disgruntled looking for help and answers. 

Mary Ambrose, who flew into New York on Friday from Toronto for business, said she couldn't find any airline official for help. 

"The board says my flight for 10:55 a.m. is on time," she said. "I want to be on that plane, but there is no one here to check me in."

At La Guardia Airport, a few flights were expected in the afternoon, as delays and cancellations were the order of the day there as well as along the East Coast. 

http://www.nytimes.com/2016/01/24/travel/the-snow-storm-is-over-but-travel-delays-arent.html

parent.title: Winter Storm on East Coast: Live Updates

And then, there were three more hours of silence in the skies, until a JetBlue flight took off for the Bahamas at 10 a.m.

In total, 12 planes arrived at Kennedy, and four departed between 7 and 11:45 a.m., according to the Federal Aviation Administration.

Nationally, more than 3,700 flights were canceled on Sunday and there have been more than 2,400 delays, according to FlightAware, a website that tracks flights.

Kennedy Airport was barren on Sunday morning, with only two taxis in front of one terminal and a scattering of would-be passengers. Many were sleeping, others walking around disgruntled looking for help and answers.

Mary Ambrose, who flew into New York on Friday from Toronto for business, said she couldn’t find any airline official for help.

“The board says my flight for 10:55 a.m. is on time,” she said. “I want to be on that plane, but there is no one here to check me in.”

At La Guardia Airport, a few flights were expected in the afternoon, as delays and cancellations were the order of the day there as well as along the East Coast.

The Snow Storm Is Over, but Travel Delays Aren’t

By THE NEW YORK TIMES

The latest updates on airline cancelations, train service and tourist sites in New York and Washington, D.C.

title: In Washington, Most Transit Remains Closed
content:
[nytmedia id="100000004164605" crop="592" type="image"]

As the Washington area transitioned from blizzard mode to cleanup mode, its two major airports — Reagan National and Dulles International — remained closed. 

Meanwhile, Washington's subway and bus mass transit system was not expected to resume service until Monday.

The Maryland M.T.A. said it hopes to resume all service by Monday.

Dulles airport, in suburban Virginia, recorded nearly 30 inches of snow, making the blizzard the second-snowiest storm on record there.
 
Interstates 70 and 270, two major highways in Maryland that were closed overnight by Gov. Larry Hogan, reopened early Sunday.

Even escalators under protected Metro canopies were blanketed in white. But a lively snowball fight in the city's Dupont Circle neighborhood — a snowstorm tradition— was underway Sunday morning.

parent.title: Winter Storm on East Coast: Live Updates

authors.name: Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Gary Gately

title: One Thing Not to Worry About: Moving Your Car
content:
[nytmedia id="100000004164587" crop="592" type="image"]

New Yorkers contemplating the horror of digging out plowed-in cars, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has a message for you: Take your time.

Alternate-side parking rules in the city will be suspended for the entire week, the governor said.
